channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Security Forces Cracked Down in Southeastern Iran
item.description: A New York Times analysis of witness testimony and videos reveals a bloody scene that unfolded last month in Zahedan during Friday Prayer, with mats as stretchers and bodies piled in cars.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Nilo Tabrizy and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Lessons From Liz Truss’s Handling of U.K. Inflation
item.description: The sharp policy U-turn by Liz Truss, Britain’s prime minister, reveals the perils of taking the wrong path in the fight against scalding inflation.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: At a news conference on Friday, Liz Truss, the British prime minister, spoke about her decisions to reinstate a planned increase in corporate taxes and fire her top finance official.

item.title: For Truss and the Tories, a ‘Fairy Tale’ Unravels
item.description: Having abandoned her signature economic plan, it remains unclear whether the British prime minister or her party can reclaim a mandate.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain during a news conference on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Asks Court to End Special Master Review of Files Seized From Trump
item.description: The Justice Department told an appeals court that a federal judge was wrong to intervene in its investigation into the former president’s hoarding of sensitive records.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department argued that all 11,000 or so documents seized from Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s estate in Florida, should not be subject to the special master review.

item.title: Trump, Reacting to Pending Jan. 6 Subpoena, Repeats Election Lies in Letter
item.description: In a rambling, 14-page restatement of false claims and conspiracy theories, the former president did not indicate whether he would testify before the House panel investigating the Capitol riot.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack voted on Thursday to issue a subpoena to former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Despite Its Barrage of Missiles, Russia Still Loses Ground in Ukraine
item.description: “They use their expensive rockets for nothing, just to frighten people,” a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said of Russian attacks on the country’s cities and infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops riding in the back of a truck near the village of Sydorov in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Elon Musk Foments More Geopolitical Controversy With Ukraine Internet Dispute
item.description: The world’s richest man, whose Starlink internet service is critical to the Ukrainian Army, said he could not “indefinitely” fund the system’s use in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Cassandra Vinograd and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX, provided Ukraine with Starlink internet service at the start of the war with Russia. Now, it’s not clear if his company will continue to fund that service.

item.title: How Republicans Learned to Love Herschel Walker
item.description: The Senate candidate in Georgia has been slammed by allegations, but he should not have been surprised. Republicans have been discussing the arrival of this moment for months.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Michael C. Bender and Maya King
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker with Senator Rick Scott, who is chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, in Carrollton, Ga., on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Ben Sasse and Veteran Republicans Soured on Senate Runs
item.description: Even as the midterms rage, veteran lawmakers are throwing up their hands and throwing in the towel.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ben Sasse’s looming departure makes him the latest lawmaker to prematurely bail out of the Senate.

item.title: The Fight for the Soul of Pilates
item.description: Long after the death of Joseph Pilates, the exercise program’s magnetic founder, his disciples are battling over his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman

item.title: Juvenile in Custody After Raleigh, N.C. Shooting Kills 5
item.description: A 15-year-old boy was in custody as investigators searched for a motive in a shooting rampage that killed an off-duty police officer and four others in Raleigh, N.C.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cataneo, Emily Cochrane and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Eamon Queeney for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shooting occurred in the Hedingham neighborhood in the northeast of Raleigh, where homes and golf courses sit near the Neuse River Greenway.

item.title: Echoes of Latin American Racism Reverberate in the U.S.
item.description: Disparaging remarks about Oaxacans from the Los Angeles City Council president shocked a city that prides itself on tolerance. But they highlighted a history of racism within the Latino community.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside City Hall in Los Angeles on Tuesday called for the resignations of three City Council members over a recording containing racist remarks. One of the three, Nury Martinez, has since resigned.

item.title: Slain Officers Faced Daunting Firepower Despite Connecticut’s Strict Gun Laws
item.description: In Bristol, residents struggled with the killing of two members of the town’s police force in an outburst of violence that left many questions unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon, Jesse McKinley and Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial became a magnet for flowers outside the Bristol Police Department on Friday.

item.title: For ‘The Great British Baking Show,’ ‘Mexican Week’ Was Not an Accident
item.description: After 12 years, the show’s long, inexorable journey from comfort to cringe is complete.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.category: The Great British Baking Show (TV Program)
item.media:description: The judges and hosts of the “Great British Baking Show” — from left, Paul Hollywood, Prue Leith, Matt Lucas and Noel Fielding — recently encountered significant backlash to the show’s “Mexican Week” episode.

item.title: Artist Helps NASA Scientists Bring Their Work to Galleries
item.description: The artist Ashley Zelinskie is helping NASA scientists share their work with wider audiences.
item.dc:creator: Matt Shaw
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors to the ONX Studio in Manhattan with Ashley Zelinskie’s “Ring Nebula” (2022), a 3-D printed sculpture, during the exhibition “Unfolding the Universe.”

item.title: Donald Trump Has Told Americans Exactly Who He Is
item.description: Even without his testimony, the Jan. 6 committee has revealed what we need to know about the former president.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Wegman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

item.title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Are Over. These 3 Things Must Happen Now.
item.description: The torch now passes to other actors who hold the power to achieve accountability for the attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Norman Eisen, Danielle Brian and E. Danya Perry
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Jon Cherry and Free Agents Limited via Getty Images

item.title: Xi Jinping Has Fallen Into the Dictator Trap
item.description: His next term could be a rough one for China as problems mount for an inflexible leader.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shirk
item.media:credit: Illustration by E S Kibele Yarman; photograph by JUAN MABROMATA / Contributor via Getty

item.title: New York Can Do More to Help the Latest Wave of Migrants
item.description: This crisis should prompt Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul to move forward with policies to build more housing in New York City and its suburbs.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yefferson Rojas is one of more than 19,400 asylum seekers who have arrived in New York since April.

item.title: This Is How to Put the Supreme Court in Its Place
item.description: Democrats in the 21st Century should not make the same mistake Republicans in the 19th Century did.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: In the Face of Inflation, Let’s Give Everyone a Lift
item.description: Cost-of-living increases shouldn’t be limited to Social Security.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: What a Report of Extreme Racism Teaches Us
item.description: Claims of especially stark and unfiltered racist abuse often do not turn out to have been true.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter

item.title: Let Haitian Schoolchildren Learn Kreyòl
item.description: Haiti cannot recover from its brutal history until its schools stop systematically demeaning its sole common language.
item.dc:creator: Michel DeGraff
item.media:description: Students on the first day of school in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Britain’s Prime Minister Liz Truss holds a press conference in the Downing Street Briefing Room in central London. Embattled British Prime Minister sacked her Treasury chief and reversed course on sweeping tax cuts Friday as she tried to hang on to her job after weeks of turmoil on financial markets. (Daniel Leal/Pool Photo via AP)

item.title: Who in the World Is Still Answering Pollsters’ Phone Calls?
item.description: Response rates suggest the “death of telephone polling” is getting closer.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Meta’s Quest Pro, Gig Economy Workers and Shocking A.I. News
item.description: Big tech is staring down the future.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Hanna Ingber, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Sophia Lanman and Rowan Niemisto

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends checking out a Tegan and Sara teen series, an underappreciated comedy and a serene backyard-farming show.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.media:description: Railey Gilliland, left, and Seazynn Gilliland in a scene from “High School.”

item.title: Nikola Founder Trevor Milton Is Convicted of Fraud
item.description: Trevor Milton was accused of boasting about nonexistent technology to inflate the stock price of Nikola, a maker of electric trucks.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Trevor Milton, left, the founder of Nikola, was accused of lying about the start-up's electric vehicles.

item.title: Robbie Coltrane, the Beloved Hagrid in ‘Harry Potter’ Films, Dies at 72
item.description: The veteran Scottish actor and comedian also played a gambling-addicted psychologist in the 1990s crime series “Cracker.”
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Robbie Coltrane at the premiere of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2” in London in 2011.

item.title: What the $24.6 Billion Kroger-Albertsons Merger Could Mean for Groceries
item.description: Two of the largest U.S. supermarket chains hope to join forces as inflation pushes food prices higher and as Amazon and Walmart become more powerful.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers inside a Kroger store in a suburb of Cincinnati, where the company is headquartered.

item.title: Alaska Cancels Snow Crab Season Amid Population Decline
item.description: Biologists say the warming of the waters of the Bering Sea in recent years is a possible factor in the decline of snow crabs.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: The Nap Bishop Is Spreading the Good Word: Rest
item.description: Tricia Hersey, founder of the Nap Ministry, sees rest as a revolutionary way to push back on America’s obsession with productivity at all costs.
item.dc:creator: Melonyce McAfee
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tricia Hersey, a.k.a. the Nap Bishop, has been experimenting with the idea of rest as liberation for nearly a decade.

item.title: Can Supplements Really Help With Depression or Anxiety?
item.description: Here’s what the evidence says about what works (and what doesn’t).
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Ecotherapists Are Working to Make the Outdoors More Inclusive
item.description: Amid pandemic stress and racial violence, many communities of color have turned to wilderness areas for healing.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Logan Lynette for The New York Times

item.title: Can Cold Water Plunges Really Reduce Anxiety and Depression?
item.description: Early research suggests this age-old practice might benefit mental health, but more research is needed.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Williams

item.title: Why Daydreaming Is Actually Good For Your Brain
item.description: Letting your mind wander can benefit the brain, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Has War Changed, or Only War Photography?
item.description: In the decades between Robert Capa and Lynsey Addario, our image of battle lost its aura of nobility.
item.dc:creator: Arthur Lubow
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times Magazine
item.media:description: A photograph by Lynsey Addario at the SVA Chelsea Gallery shows Specialist Carl Vandeberge, center, and Sgt. Kevin Rice, behind, being helped to a helicopter for evacuation after they were both shot in the stomach during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in 2007.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
